As an NGO/paralegal, you can:
1. Help lodge FIR and give a detailed Section 161 CrPC statement.
2. Ensure early Section 164 CrPC statement before a Magistrate.
3. Request appointment of a “support person” through DLSA/JJ system.
4. Seek interim and final compensation from DLSA.
5. During trial, insist on child‑friendly measures under Sections 24 and 33 POCSO: in‑camera hearing, no aggressive questioning, screens/video‑link if needed. Always prioritise the [Victim]’s emotional safety.

input: Mera case kuch aisa hai: [Victim] mentally aur physically disabled child hai. Usne sign language se apni maa ko bataya ki [Accused] ne uske saath galat touch kiya. Police ne FIR karke IPC 354A aur POCSO laga diya tha, charge-sheet bhi gayi, lekin trial court ne evidence reliable nahi maana aur acquit kar diya. Judge ko sign language aur child ki condition pe trust nahi hua. Aise situation me hum log kya legal steps le sakte hain? Kya acquittal ke against appeal possible hai?
output:
Aap jo bata rahe hain, wo bahut painful situation hai, especially jab child disabled ho. Law ke hisaab se acquittal ke against appeal possible hai.

1) State appeal: Normally State government / Public Prosecutor High Court me appeal file kar sakte hain.
2) Victim/maa appeal: CrPC ke proviso to Section 372 ke under victim ko bhi appeal ka right hai, lekin usually High Court ki permission (leave) chahi hoti hai.

Child ki disability, sign language, POCSO ki special protection sab points appeal me highlight kiye ja sakte hain.

input: Court ne yeh bhi bola tha ki sign language se jo baat maa tak aayi wo strong nahi hai, jaise hearsay ho. Mujhe samajhna hai, law me aise child ka evidence ka kya value hota hai? Mentally retarded bachche ki testimony ya gestures ko kaise treat karna chahiye tha? Kya Indian Evidence Act me iske bare me kuch clear provision hai, especially jab child bol nahi sakta aur sirf signs se batata hai?
output:
Indian Evidence Act me clear hai ki aise child ka evidence ignore nahi kiya ja sakta.

1) Section 118: Jo witness “understands questions and can give rational answers” hai, wo competent hai – isme disabled child bhi aa sakta hai.
2) Section 119: Jo witness bol nahi sakta, wo signs ya writing se evidence de sakta hai, interpreter ke through.

POCSO Section 26 child‑friendly recording ka bolta hai. Maa sirf interpreter/communicator ki role me ho sakti hai; sirf hearsay karke side‑line karna sahi approach nahi maana jata.

input: Ab practical side se batao, acquittal ho chuka hai, toh kya [Victim] ki maa khud High Court me appeal ya revision file kar sakti hai? Usko kaunse steps follow karne honge, koi time limit hoti hai kya? Aur agar hamare paas private lawyer afford karne ke paise nahi hain, toh free legal aid ka option available hai kya aise POCSO matters me?
output:
Haan, kuch options hain:

1) Appeal: Maa “victim” ke roop me CrPC Section 372 proviso ke under High Court me appeal file kar sakti hai, usually State ke khilaf nahi, balki accused ke acquittal ke against. Often 90 days ka limitation period hota hai, delay condone bhi ho sakta hai.

2) Legal aid: District Legal Services Authority (DLSA) se free lawyer mil sakta hai. POCSO aur disabled child matters me legal aid strongly available hota hai; aap written application de sakte hain.

input: Agar appeal file karne me time lag jaye, tab tak child ki safety ka kya? [Accused] hamare area me hi rehta hai. Kya police se koi protective order ya restraint le sakte hain? Ya hume kisi Child Welfare Committee ya kisi aur authority ko approach karna chahiye future risk ke liye? Main chahta hoon ki [Victim] ko dobara usse face na karna pade.
output:
Child ki safety abhi sabse important hai.

1) Police: Local police station me written application dekar request karein ki [Accused] se threat hai; daily diary / GD me note karwaayein. Police CrPC Sections 107–151 ke under preventive action le sakti hai.
2) Childline 1098: Call karke case explain karein; woh CWC tak connect kara sakte hain.
3) Child Welfare Committee / JJ Act: CWC se protection measures, counselling, support person arrange ho sakta hai.
4) Agar possible ho toh school/ghar ke routes, supervision, sab strengthen karein.

input: Maan lijiye ek 10th class ki ladki hai, [Victim], jisko ek neighbour [Accused] roz school aate–jaate follow karta hai, raste me rokta hai, badtameez comments karta hai aur dhamki deta hai ki agar mana kiya to dekh lunga. Parents tension me hain. Is type situation me kaun kaun se law apply hote hain? POCSO lagega kya ya sirf IPC? Aur kya straight FIR police station me file kar sakte hain?
output:
Aap jo bata rahe hain woh serious child safety issue hai, isko lightly nahi lena chahiye.

Law ke hisaab se:
- IPC me Section 354, 354A (sexual harassment), 354D (stalking), 341 (wrongful restraint), 506 (criminal intimidation) apply ho sakte hain.
- Kyunki [Victim] minor hai, POCSO Act bhi lagega, specially Section 7–8 (sexual assault type touching) ya 11–12 (sexual harassment), facts pe depend karega.

Aap direct nearest police station me FIR register karwa sakte hain, ya 112/1098 par help le sakte hain.

input: Agar FIR ho jaye to kya court generally aise cases me accused ko jaldi bail de deta hai? Parents ko darr hai ki agar [Accused] bahar aa gaya to aur zyada dhamka sakta hai. Kya court se protection ya no‑contact type order mil sakta hai? Maine ek Haryana case ke baare me suna tha jahan court ne bola tha ki child abuse ke cases me leniency nahi honi chahiye, uska kya effect hota hai?
output:
Child ke cases me court normally zyada strict hota hai, especially jab stalking, threat aur POCSO sections lage hon.

Bail decide karte waqt court yeh dekhta hai:
- Offence ki seriousness
- Victim ki safety
- Koi repeat threat hai ya nahi

Aap victim side se bail oppose kar sakte hain, apne lawyer ke through written reply dekar.

Court bail grant kare to bhi strong conditions laga sakta hai: no‑contact with [Victim], school/ghar ke area me na aana, witness ko threaten na karna, etc. Violation pe bail cancel ho sakti hai.

input: Victim ki statement ka process kaise hota hai? Parents ko dar hai ki police ya court me baar‑baar poocha jayega to [Victim] mentally disturb ho jayegi. Kya POCSO me koi child‑friendly procedure hota hai jisse usko kam se kam baar statement deni pade? Aur kya female officer ke saamne statement demand kar sakte hain?
output:
POCSO specifically child‑friendly procedure provide karta hai.

Important points:
- POCSO Section 24: police ko child‑friendly tarike se statement leni hoti hai, preferably ghar ya safe jagah par.
- As far as possible lady police officer assign ki jati hai; aap clearly request kar sakte hain.
- Child ke saath parent/ trusted adult rehen, yeh generally allow hota hai.
- Court me later Section 164 CrPC ke under Magistrate ke saamne statement record hoti hai, taki baar‑baar detailed questioning avoid ho aur record preserve rahe.

input: Agar parents abhi thoda hesitant hain to kya pehle Childline ya school counsellor se baat karke phir police ke paas jana better hoga? Ya directly police ke paas hi jana chahiye? Aur kya complaint anonymous ho sakti hai, kyunki mohalla me badnaam hone ka bhi dar hai. Reporting ke liye koi time limit hoti hai kya aise offences me?
output:
Law ke hisaab se, POCSO Section 19 ke under jo bhi adult ko pata chale, usko report karna chahiye.

Options:
- Direct police station me jaa kar FIR
- Childline 1098 call karke guidance aur support
- School principal/teacher ko likhit complaint; woh bhi police ko inform kar sakte hain

Victim ki identity law se protected rehti hai (naam, address public nahi kar sakte). Serious sexual offences me generally strict time‑limit nahi hoti, par jitni jaldi report karenge utna evidence strong hoga.

input: Sir please help, kal CBI wale ghar aaye the. Mere bhai [Accused] ka phone aur ek hard disk le gaye, bol rahe the ki bachchon ke gande videos group me share hue hain. Mujhe kuch samajh nahi aa raha, ye itna serious hai kya? Bhai bol raha hai bas forward hua tha, usne banaya nahi. Main bahut dar gaya hoon.
output: Main samajh sakta hoon aap kitne tense honge. Haan, child sexual abuse videos circulate / store karna bahut serious offence hai. Is type ke cases generally POCSO Act ke provisions (jaise Section 13–15) aur IT Act Section 67B ke under aate hain, kabhi‑kabhi IPC bhi lag sakta hai. CBI digital evidence jaise phone, hard disk examine karegi. Abhi sabse pehle aapko ek criminal lawyer se milna chahiye jo CBI / cyber crime matters handle karta ho. Agar kisi real [Victim] child ka pata ho, uski safety ko priority dein.

input: Par sir agar usne sirf WhatsApp group me aaya hua video dekh liya ya aage bhej diya, to bhi utni hi badi problem hogi? Use lag raha hai ki bas admin ki galti hai. Jail ho sakti hai kya? Aur kya bachche ke saath jo hua uske liye bhi hum pe case aa sakta hai?
output: Law ke hisaab se sirf forward / store karna bhi offence hai. POCSO Section 15 aur IT Act Section 67B me child sexual abuse material ka possession, download, share karna punishable hai, chahe aapne video banaya ho ya nahi. Punishment generally jail + fine ho sakta hai, duration facts pe depend karega. Agar aapka bhai khud kisi [Victim] ke sexual abuse me involve nahi tha, to POCSO Section 3–10 ya IPC 354, 376 jaise sections shayad directly uspe na lagen, lekin exact position file mein evidence dekh ke lawyer batayega.

input: CBI wale bol rahe the phone me kaafi videos mile hain. Kya court me sabko dikhayenge? Family ko bhi bulayenge kya? Aur agar koi minor child identify ho gaya to uska kya hoga, usko court me ana padega kya? Mujhe us bachche ke liye bhi bura lag raha hai.
output: Aapka concern sahi hai. Court generally aise videos open court me nahi chalati; in‑camera proceedings hoti hain, child‑friendly process follow hota hai. POCSO Section 24, 33, 36, 37 ke hisaab se [Victim] child ka statement child‑friendly tariqe se hota hai, zaroori hua to video‑conferencing, screen, support person ke saath. Family members sirf witness ke roop me bulae ja sakte hain, agar unke paas relevant information ho. Investigation agencies try karti hain ki child ko minimum trauma ho, counselling aur protection measures bhi available hote hain.

input: Sir ek aur baat, group me bahut log the, kuch bahar ke country ke bhi. Kya main CBI ko unka detail de sakta hoon? Ya online complaint karni hogi? Mujhe darr lagta hai par galat log bach na jayein. Mere naam se koi dikkat to nahi hogi?
output: Bilkul, aap un sab logon / admins ki information CBI investigator ko de sakte hain, ye helpful hoga. Aap national cyber crime portal (cybercrime.gov.in) par bhi child sexual abuse material ki online complaint kar sakte hain. POCSO Section 19 reporting ko encourage karta hai; aap jaise log jo information rakhte hain, woh report kar sakte hain. Aapka statement witness ke taur pe record ho sakta hai, lekin law aapko offender jaisa treat nahi karega sirf isliye ki aapne help ki. Agar dar lag raha ho to lawyer ke through bhi details de sakte hain.

input: Abhi turant mujhe kya karna chahiye? CBI ne bulaaya to kya bolun, lawyer ke bina jana theek hai? Aur ghar me ek minor [Relative] bhi hai, usko bhi tension ho rahi hai. Uske liye koi help ya counselling mil sakti hai kya free me?
output: Steps yeh ho sakte hain: 1) Jaldi se ek experienced criminal / cyber lawyer engage karein, ideally CBI enquiry me uske saath hi jayein. 2) Evidence chhupane / delete karne ki koshish bilkul na karein, varna alag offence ban sakta hai. 3) Ghar ke minor [Relative] ke liye counselling chahiye ho to Childline 1098 par call karein; free support mil sakta hai. 4) Agar paise ki dikkat ho to District Legal Services Authority se free legal aid lawyer maang sakte hain. Har baat sach‑sach lawyer ko batayein.

input: We are assisting an 11‑year‑old [Child], adopted by [Adoptive Mother]. The child disclosed possible sexual abuse at home to a school teacher. The school informed authorities, and the Child Welfare Committee (CWC) has placed the child in a girls’ home, denying custody to the adoptive mother, who has filed a writ for restoration. Can you explain, in general, what powers the CWC has under the JJ Act to keep an adopted child away from the adoptive parent during such allegations, and how this interacts with any POCSO proceedings?
output: Under the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015, the CWC can treat the child as a “child in need of care and protection” and assume charge (Sections 27–30, 36–37). It may place the child in a child care institution or fit facility, even against parental wishes, if there is risk of abuse or influence. This is a temporary, protective measure, reviewed periodically. A parallel POCSO case (Sections 3–10, etc.) proceeds independently before the police and Special Court. High Courts, in writs, usually consider the child’s safety and wishes, not just parental rights.

input: On mandatory reporting: in this kind of situation, who carries the duty under Section 19 of the POCSO Act? Is it only the teacher, or also the school management and even the adoptive mother once she becomes aware? What are the broad consequences of non‑reporting under Section 21, and is there any protection for good‑faith reporters who may be unsure whether the facts amount to an offence?
output: Section 19 POCSO imposes a duty on “any person” who has apprehension or knowledge of an offence to report it to the police or Special Juvenile Police Unit. This includes the teacher, school authorities, family members, and the adoptive mother. Under Section 21, failure to report can attract punishment (fine and/or imprisonment). However, the Act protects good‑faith reporting; you are not required to be certain of the offence, only to report reasonable suspicion. Schools may also have institutional obligations via circulars and child protection policies, but those are in addition to the statutory duty.

input: Regarding the child’s statement: once the report is made, how should her statement be formally recorded to remain child‑friendly and legally valid? Is it correct that a statement under Section 164 CrPC before a Magistrate and child‑friendly procedures under Section 24 POCSO are expected? Can the CWC itself record any detailed statement, or should it limit itself to a brief interaction to avoid repeated questioning and re‑traumatisation?
output: Yes, typically: police take an initial statement in a child‑friendly manner (Section 24 POCSO) and then request a Section 164 CrPC statement before a Magistrate, also in a supportive environment. That 164 statement is crucial evidence. The CWC may interact with the child to assess safety, needs, and placement, but should avoid detailed, repeated questioning about the abuse. Its role is protective and rehabilitative, not investigative. You can request coordination between police, CWC, and Magistrate so the child gives core details only a minimal number of times.

input: In the custody aspect: does the adoptive mother have any right to meet or speak with the child while the CWC inquiry and POCSO investigation are ongoing? How do authorities balance the presumption of innocence of the alleged offender with the child’s best interests? Does the presumption under Section 29 POCSO have any role at the CWC stage, or is it limited to the Special Court’s trial?
output: Contact is decided by the CWC based on risk and best interests. If the alleged abuser is in the same household, the CWC may restrict or deny access, or allow only supervised meetings, depending on the child’s wishes and safety plan. The criminal law presumption under Section 29 POCSO applies at the Special Court stage, not to CWC’s care‑and‑protection decisions. At CWC level, the standard is precautionary: even without a criminal finding, credible risk can justify temporary separation to protect the child from pressure or harm.

input: If the adoptive mother wants to seek restoration through the CWC rather than only through writ proceedings, what are the usual procedural steps? Can she file an application before the CWC with the adoption order and other documents, and ask for review of the placement? Is there any statutory requirement for periodic review of such institutional placement, and does she have a right to be heard in those reviews?
output: She can submit a written application to the CWC, enclosing the adoption order and identity documents, explaining her version, supports available, and safeguards. The CWC may order a social investigation report and consult police, counsellors, and the child. Under JJ Act provisions on restoration and periodic review (e.g., Sections 36–37), the CWC must review the child’s placement at intervals and consider restoration when safe. Parents/guardians generally have a right to notice and to be heard, though the child’s views and protection needs remain paramount in every review.

input: As an NGO, we want to support [Child] without interfering in the process. Under POCSO and JJ frameworks, can we act as a “support person” for her—helping her attend CWC hearings, medicals, and court, and ensuring she understands what is happening? Should we route this through the DCPU or directly request the CWC/police to appoint us? Any pitfalls we should avoid to remain trauma‑informed and legally appropriate?
output: Under POCSO Rules 2020 (e.g., Rule 4), a support person can be appointed, often from an NGO, through the District Child Protection Unit (DCPU) or on CWC/police recommendation. You can write to the DCPU and CWC offering to act as support person. Your role: explain procedures in simple language, accompany the child, coordinate services, and prevent contact with the alleged offender. Avoid discussing case details beyond what professionals request, avoid coaching testimony, and prioritise the child’s choices, privacy, and emotional safety in every interaction.

input: Sir please help… main choti thi jab ek uncle ne ghar se kheench ke apne chawal ke mill pe le gaye the, biscuit ka lalach deke. Mummy khet me thi. Main abhi unke khilaf case chal raha hai, mujhe court me kisi judge ke saamne statement likhwaaya gaya tha pehle. Mujhe bahut dar lagta hai, samajh nahi aa raha aage kya hoga, kya main kuch aur kar sakti hoon? Mujhe aur baar baar sab bolna padega kya?
output:
Aapki jo baat hui thi judge ke saamne, woh statement CrPC Section 164 ke under record hua hoga, yeh bahut important evidence hota hai, isliye aapne jo sach bola hai woh already record ho chuka hai.

Yeh matter child sexual abuse hai, generally POCSO Act ke under aata hai (jaise Section 3–4 ya 7–8, facts pe depend karega), saath me IPC Section 354 / 376 bhi lag sakte hain.

Aap 1098 Childline ya District Legal Services Authority se free legal aid aur counselling bhi le sakti hain.

input: Par didi, mujhe sabse zyada dar yahi lagta hai ki kya mujhe court me uss aadmi ke saamne khade hoke phir se sab batana padega? Main ab bhi bahut darr jaati hoon, raat ko neend nahi aati. Kya court me mere liye kuch protection hota hai? Main judge se aise baat kar sakti hoon ki woh room me na ho? Mujhe samajh nahi aa raha process kya hoga.
output:
Aapka dar bilkul valid hai. Law me aapke liye protection provisions hain.

POCSO ke hisaab se trial in-camera hota hai, matlab open public nahi hoti, sirf zaroori log. Court aapse alag room se video conferencing ya screen ke peeche se statement lene ka order de sakti hai, taaki aap [Accused] ko seedha na dekhna pade.

POCSO Section 33(5) ke mutabik aapse unnecessary baar‑baar sawaal nahi puchne chahiye. Aap apne lawyer ya judge ko clearly yeh request rakh sakti hain.

input: Main ek NGO mein paralegal hoon. Ek matter hai jahan [Victim] ki biological age 19 hai, lekin intellectual disability ke wajah se mental age approx 7–8 years ke around hai. Alleged sexual assault [Accused] ne kiya hai. Eera v. State wale Supreme Court judgment ke baad kya aise case mein POCSO apply ho sakta hai ya phir sirf IPC Sections (376/354 etc.) hi lag sakte hain? Court mental age ko “child” ke scope mein kaise dekhta hai abhi? Strategy decide karni hai before FIR draft karein.
output:
Aap bahut important situation handle kar rahe hain, aur [Victim] ki safety aur dignity sabse pehle aati hai.

Eera judgment ke baad bhi POCSO mein “child” ki definition Section 2(1)(d) ke hisaab se sirf biological age <18 hi maana jata hai. Supreme Court ne mental age ko include karne se mana kiya, bola ki yeh kaam Parliament ka hai.

Isliye 19-year-old ke case mein generally POCSO nahi lagega; aap IPC Sections 375/376, 376(2)(l), 354 etc. ke under FIR karwa sakte hain, par victim-friendly procedure ke liye Eera ka reasoning cite kar sakte hain.

input: Thik hai. Ab ek doubt hai: kyunki POCSO technically apply nahi ho raha, kya Section 19 POCSO ka mandatory reporting hum NGO staff par lagega? Ya is case mein reporting CrPC/IPC ke general framework ke through karni hogi? Dusra point: kya hum investigation aur trial stage par written application dekar POCSO-type safeguards (in-camera, support person, special educator, minimal questioning) demand kar sakte hain, relying on Eera reasoning, even though case strictly IPC ke under hai?
output:
Section 19 POCSO ka mandatory reporting tabhi trigger hota hai jab “child” ho, yani <18 years. Is case mein technically POCSO Section 19 apply nahi karega.

Phir bhi, aap CrPC Section 39 ke general duty ke basis par serious offences ki information police ko de sakte hain, ideally guardian/appointed guardian ke saath.

Safeguards ke liye aap written applications de sakte hain:
- CrPC Section 164 statement ke waqt special educator/support person
- CrPC Sections 273 & 327(2) ke tahat in-camera, victim-friendly environment
Aur in sab ko support karne ke liye Eera judgment aur disability jurisprudence ka reference de sakte hain.

input: FIR draft karte waqt kya hum explicitly mention karein ki [Victim] ki mental age child ke barabar hai aur Eera judgment cite karke specific protections maangein, jaise lady IO, familiar setting mein statement, counsellor/support person ki presence, video-recording etc.? Kya yeh practical hai ya police usually resist karti hai? Aur Childline 1098 ko involve karna is scenario mein legally appropriate hoga, given ki biological age 18 se upar hai?
output:
FIR/complaint mein clearly likhna useful hoga ki [Victim] intellectually disabled hai, functioning child ke level par hai, aur Eera judgment ka reference dekar victim-sensitive procedure request kar sakte hain:
- lady IO
- possible ho to ghar/NGO ya hospital setting mein statement (CrPC 161/164)
- counsellor/support person aur special educator ki presence
- later stage par in-camera proceedings (CrPC 327(2)).

Police kabhi-kabhi resist kar sakti hai, par likhit request helpful hoti hai. 1098 technically children ke liye hai, lekin aap guidance/referral ke liye call kar sakte hain; actual offence reporting ke liye local police/112 aur DLSA approach karein.

input: My 13‑year‑old nephew’s photo was taken from social media, morphed in a sexual way, and shared in an office WhatsApp group by two employees, [Accused 1] and [Accused 2]. Both work in an IT/pharma company. Can this come under POCSO, or only under the IT Act? Can IPC also apply? Police are saying it is just an IT matter and not a “child sexual abuse” case. What is the correct legal position generally?
output:
I am sorry your nephew and family are going through this. From what you describe, it generally fits child sexual abuse online.

Legally, multiple laws can apply together:
- POCSO Act: creating and circulating sexual images of a child can fall under sexual assault/harassment and child pornography (for example, Sections 3–10, 11, 13, 14, 19).
- IT Act: Section 67B (publishing/transmitting material depicting children in sexually explicit acts).
- IPC: sections like 354A (sexual harassment), 509 (insulting modesty), 292 (obscene material).

Courts have held that IPC and IT Act can both be invoked when facts fit.

input: The local police insist they will register only under the IT Act and say it is bailable and they will just warn them. Can I specifically demand POCSO and some IPC sections to be added? Is there any general legal principle that IPC and IT Act can both be used? How should I put this in a written complaint so they take it seriously?
output:
You are entitled to ask for proper sections to be considered.

1. In your written complaint, clearly mention:
- Child’s age and relationship.
- That the images are sexual/morphed and shared in a group.
- Request registration under POCSO (sexual assault/harassment and pornography), IT Act Section 67B, and IPC Sections 354A, 509, 292.

2. Legal principle: the IT Act is a special law, but it does not automatically exclude IPC; where facts satisfy offences in both, both can generally be applied.

3. If police still refuse, you may approach the Superintendent of Police or file an application under Section 156(3) CrPC before the Magistrate.

input: I am also worried about my nephew’s mental state. Will he have to go to the police station and repeat everything? How is his statement taken in such online sexual abuse cases? What can we do to protect him from more trauma and at the same time secure the digital evidence properly?
output:
Your concern for his wellbeing is very important.

1. Under POCSO (Sections 19, 24, 26, 27), child‑friendly procedures apply:
- Statement should preferably be recorded at home or a safe place, not a regular police station.
- By a trained officer, in simple language, with a parent or trusted adult present.
- Effort to avoid repeated questioning.

2. Evidence handling:
- Save screenshots, URLs, chat logs; do not forward them further.
- Keep original devices safely; police should seize/clon­e them properly.

3. Support:
- Call Childline 1098.
- Approach District Legal Services Authority or a child‑rights NGO for counselling and legal aid.
- JJ Act mechanisms can also provide care and protection if needed.

input: please help. my second husband [Accused] did bad things to my small son [Victim] early morning when I went for house work. I complained in police station, now case is going in big court in Bangalore. I am very scared, I dont understand anything. is this really strong case? what law protects my child? I am also afraid [Accused] will come near us again.
output:
I am very sorry this happened to you and [Victim]. From what you describe, this is a serious crime against a child.

In India, such acts are covered mainly by the POCSO Act. When the person is a step‑father, it can be treated as aggravated sexual assault or aggravated penetrative sexual assault (more serious). IPC provisions on sexual assault can also apply.

You may:
- Inform the Investigating Officer about any threats
- Ask for protection
- Call Childline 1098
- Stay with trusted relatives or in a shelter if you feel unsafe.

input: my son [Victim] is very scared to go to court. will he have to sit in same room and see [Accused]? he cries when he remembers. also that time only [Accused] and my son were inside house, no one saw. will court still believe my son?
output:
The law tries to protect children in court.

Under the POCSO Act, the judge can:
- Hold the trial in a closed (in‑camera) court
- Allow a screen or separate room so [Victim] does not see [Accused]
- Permit a support person or family member to stay with him

The child’s statement is important evidence, even if no one else saw. There can also be medical evidence and his earlier statement to police or magistrate. Tell the public prosecutor about his fear so they can request child‑friendly arrangements.

input: police already took my and my son statement. lawyer of [Accused] is saying I made false case because of family fight. I feel very scared when he say like that. what can I do to support the case? what things I should keep or tell court?
output:
You have done the right thing by reporting.

You can:
- Keep all medical reports, police complaints, and copies of statements safely
- Tell the prosecutor about any earlier incidents, threats, or witnesses (neighbours, relatives, teacher) who noticed changes in [Victim]
- Share any phone messages or calls showing pressure or harassment

Do not coach [Victim]; just tell him to speak truth in simple words. You can meet the public prosecutor before each hearing to understand what will happen that day and clarify doubts.

input: I dont have much money. case is in sessions court, they say. can I get free lawyer? who will speak for my son? also my son is very disturbed, is there any place or people for counselling or safe stay if needed?
output:
In such cases, the State appoints a Public Prosecutor to conduct the case, so you do not have to pay. You can also ask the District Legal Services Authority (DLSA) for a free support lawyer.

For [Victim]’s safety and counselling, you may:
- Call Childline 1098
- Request help from the Child Welfare Committee through police or DLSA
- Seek NGO support for therapy and, if needed, temporary shelter

Tell the court and police clearly if you fear further harm, so they can arrange protection.

input: We are supporting [Victim], whose minor daughter was allegedly kidnapped, after which her husband died by suicide due to mental harassment by [Accused]. The police have registered serious IPC offences, and [Accused] has sought anticipatory bail under Section 438 CrPC. From a victim-protection angle, how does a court usually weigh such allegations involving a minor (possibly engaging POCSO) and abetment to suicide when deciding anticipatory bail, especially where evidence of direct instigation is said to be weak?
output:
I am sorry the family is going through this. In anticipatory bail, the court generally looks at:

- Nature and gravity of offences (kidnapping of a minor, any POCSO angle, abetment to suicide)
- Available prima facie material (messages, threats, past complaints)
- Specific role of [Accused], not just broad allegations
- Risk of absconding or tampering with witnesses, especially the minor
- Need for custodial interrogation

If evidence of direct instigation is weak, courts may lean towards bail but can impose strict conditions to protect [Victim] and the child.

input: In this case, the complaint suggests earlier threats and a dispute linked to the daughter’s kidnapping, but there was no immediate POCSO or kidnap FIR when the child issue first arose. Under Section 19 POCSO, does the delay or failure to make a mandatory report weaken the minor’s case now? How can we, as an NGO, frame this issue so the court does not treat the delay as lack of credibility?
output:
Section 19 POCSO requires any person with knowledge of a POCSO offence to report, but delay does not automatically weaken the case. Courts recognise fear, stigma, pressure, and lack of awareness.

You can:
- Explain in writing the reasons for delay (fear of [Accused], family pressure, lack of legal support).
- Emphasise consistent core allegations over time.
- Highlight that mandatory reporting is a legal duty, but non-compliance should not prejudice the child.
- Request the court to focus on present evidence and the child’s current safety needs.

input: During the anticipatory bail hearing, our priority is safety of the minor and [Victim]. What specific conditions under Section 438(2) CrPC can we request the court or prosecutor to seek, so that even if anticipatory bail is granted, there is minimal risk of intimidation or further trauma to the child and mother?
output:
You can request conditions such as:

- No contact (direct or indirect) with [Victim], the minor, or key witnesses.
- Not entering their neighbourhood, school, or workplace.
- Regular appearance before the IO and full cooperation with investigation.
- Not posting about the case or the child on social media.
- Surrendering passport, if needed.

You may convey these to the public prosecutor, victim’s counsel, and, if involved, the Child Welfare Committee. Also consider Childline 1098 for additional safety planning.

input: My son [Accused] and a girl [Victim] were in a love relationship. She became pregnant. Both families finally agreed for marriage, but when she went to a government hospital in Puducherry, the doctors informed the police and a POCSO case was filed. Now there is a charge sheet in the Special Court and we have filed a petition to quash it. Was the hospital required to inform the police? Since it was a love affair, can the case be quashed? What legal points should we discuss with our lawyer?
output:
From what you describe, it sounds very stressful for everyone involved.

1. Under the POCSO Act, Section 19 makes reporting to police mandatory for doctors when they suspect sexual offence against a person below 18, so the hospital was legally bound to inform.
2. Consent of a minor is not recognised in law, so a “love affair” is usually still treated as an offence (often under POCSO Sections 3/4, sometimes IPC 375/376).
3. For quashing, High Courts look at age proof, genuineness of relationship, absence of coercion, and wishes of the girl and her family. Your lawyer can assess documents, medical records, and statements in the charge sheet in detail.

input: If the girl and her parents state clearly that it was a voluntary relationship and that they want the marriage to go ahead, will that help to quash the case or at least get bail more easily? Also, is there any risk for parents or doctors if they do not report such cases under this child safety law?
output:
Supportive statements from the girl and her parents usually help for bail and may influence the High Court while considering quashing, especially where there is a genuine, non‑exploitative relationship. But their consent cannot legally erase the offence if she was under 18.

Under POCSO Sections 19 and 21, any person (including doctors, teachers, relatives) who fails to report a known offence can face punishment. Doctors have a clear statutory duty. Parents also have a general duty to report, though prosecutions for parents are less common.

For any safety concerns, [Victim] can also seek support through Childline 1098.

input: We are supporting a 10th standard girl [Victim] in Delhi. A neighbour [Accused] repeatedly stalked her, waits outside her house, and uses obscene, abusive language. Police came on a DD entry and took a written complaint from the child. As an NGO, we want to clarify: does this conduct fall under POCSO (e.g., sexual harassment) or only IPC provisions like Section 354D and 509? Also, does Section 19 POCSO make reporting mandatory for us in these facts, and is an FIR based on a minor’s complaint alone legally sufficient?
output:
Based on your description, it may amount to sexual harassment under Section 11 POCSO (punishable under Section 12) and stalking under Section 354D IPC, and use of obscene words under Section 509 IPC.

Under Section 19 POCSO, any person (including NGO staff) with knowledge of such sexual offences must report to police or Special Juvenile Police Unit.

An FIR can legally be registered on the sole statement of a minor. Under Section 154 CrPC, police must record information about a cognizable offence and start investigation.

input: The child is very anxious about repeated questioning. What are the correct procedures for recording her statement? Specifically: (a) difference between police statement and 164 CrPC statement before Magistrate; (b) how POCSO Section 24 child‑friendly procedures apply (e.g., at home or NGO office, female officer, no uniform); and (c) whether we can request a counsellor/psychologist to be present during these proceedings in Delhi.
output:
First, police record a Section 161 CrPC statement, ideally by a woman officer, in a child‑friendly place. Later, a Magistrate may record a Section 164 CrPC statement, which carries higher evidentiary value.

Under Section 24 POCSO, the statement should be recorded at the child’s residence or a safe place, preferably by a woman, in plain clothes, without aggressive questioning. A trusted adult/NGO worker can usually be present.

You may request a counsellor or psychologist through the IO, the Child Welfare Committee, or the District Legal Services Authority.

input: We are worried about further harassment because the [Accused] lives in the same lane. What immediate legal protection is realistically available? Can we seek specific bail conditions (non‑contact, not loitering near her house/school), involvement of the Child Welfare Committee for a safety plan, or any preventive steps by local police? Please outline practical steps we should take with the IO and prosecutor.
output:
You can request the IO and prosecutor to seek strict bail conditions under Sections 437–439 CrPC: no contact with [Victim], no visiting her house, lane, or school, and no threats to witnesses.

Ask the IO to note these risks in the case diary and inform the court.

You may approach the Child Welfare Committee for a safety plan and counselling.

You can also request local police to make preventive visits and, where appropriate, take action under Section 149 CrPC to prevent further offences.

input: Sir please help, mera bhatija [Minor] ko police ne pakad liya hai, bol rahe hain ki uske upar chhote bacche ke saath gandi harkat ka case hai. Court ne bola woh abhi chhota hai, par phir bhi usko chhod nahi rahe, bail reject ho gayi. Judge ne kuch report ka naam liya aur bola galat logon ke contact mein aa sakta hai. Mujhe kuch samajh nahi aa raha, main kya karu?
output:
Mujhe samajh aa raha hai aap bahut pareshaan hain, aisa case bahut stressful hota hai.

Aapke bhatije par shayad POCSO Act ke under case bana hoga (jaise Section 3–7 sexual assault ke liye) aur saath mein IPC Sections 354 / 376 bhi ho sakte hain. Kyunki woh minor hai, uska matter Juvenile Justice Board ke paas hai.

Bail juvenile ke liye JJ Act ke Section 12 mein hoti hai, par court ne shayad social investigation report dekh kar yeh bola ki woh galat logon se jud sakta hai.

input: Haan ji, judge ne bola koi social investigation report mein likha hai ki woh criminal type logon ke saath reh sakta hai, isliye ghar nahi bhej rahe. Yeh report hota kya hai? Agar woh galat likh diya gaya ho toh? Hum log normal family hain, bas gareeb hain. Ab hum log kya kar sakte hain, fir se bail maang sakte hain kya?
output:
Social investigation report usually probation officer / DCPU wale banate hain, JJ Act ke hisaab se. Isme family ka background, ghar ka mahaul, school record, kisi criminal gang se link hai ya nahi – yeh sab likha jata hai.

Agar report mein aapko lagta hai galat ya adhura cheez likhi hai, to aap apne lawyer ke through:
- Court ko additional documents de sakte hain (school certificate, neighbours ke affidavits, etc.)
- Higher court mein revision/appeal file karwa sakte hain JJ Act Section 102 ke hisaab se
- Dobara bail ki application daal sakte hain agar circumstances change dikhayein.

input: Sir ek baat aur, mujhe sabse zyada dar yahi lag raha hai ki mera bhatija jail mein bada criminals ke saath to nahi rakha hoga? Woh to abhi school jaata tha, bilkul dara hua hai. Kya minor ko bhi jail bhejte hain? Uski safety ka kya hoga wahan?
output:
Aap thoda tasalli rakhiye, law ke mutabik minor ko normal jail mein adults ke saath nahi rakha jata.

Juvenile ke case mein usko Observation Home / Place of Safety mein rakha jata hai, JJ Act ke under. Wahan staff ko bachchon ke saath kaam karne ke liye train kiya jata hai.

Aap lawyer se request kar sakte hain ki:
- Court se poochhein ki woh exactly kis Observation Home mein hai
- Uski education, counselling aur safety ke arrangements ke baare mein report mangwayen.

Agar kisi bhi child ko abuse ka risk ho, Childline 1098 par call kiya ja sakta hai.

input: Humare NGO ke paas ek matter aaya jo State vs Lakhan jaisa hai. 13 saal ki [Victim] ne initially bola ki ek drunk [Accused] ne haath pakda, thappad mara, FIR 323/354-B IPC aur 8 POCSO ke under hui. Lekin trial mein [Victim] aur maa hostile ho gaye, misunderstanding bol diya, aur acquittal ho gaya. Aise cases mein court generally kis legal principle ke basis par acquit karti hai jab main witnesses hostile ho jate hain?
output:
Aise criminal cases mein court ka basic principle hai “beyond reasonable doubt”. POCSO ya IPC offence prove karne ke liye prosecution ko credible, consistent evidence dikhani hoti hai. 

Jab prosecutrix aur maa jaise material witnesses hostile ho jate hain, unka court statement (examination-in-chief + cross) agar offence ko support nahi karta, toh sirf FIR ya 161 CrPC statement ke basis par conviction mushkil ho jata hai, kyunki woh substantive evidence nahi hote. Is wajah se court benefit of doubt dekar acquit kar deti hai.

input: Field level par confusion hota hai: POCSO Section 19 ke hisaab se mandatory reporting toh hai, lekin baad mein family bolti hai ki misunderstanding thi, case nahi chalana. Agar hum NGO worker ne information dekar FIR register karwa di, aur baad mein victim hostile ho gayi, toh kya hum par koi legal risk ya liability ho sakti hai Section 19 ke context mein?
output:
POCSO Section 19 mandatory reporting lagata hai: jis bhi person ko reasonable suspicion ho, usse police ya SJPU ko inform karna chahiye. Aapne good faith mein report kiya ho, toh Section 19(7) aapko protection deta hai—good faith reporting ke liye normally koi liability nahi banti.

Family ka baad mein “misunderstanding” kehna case ko weak kar sakta hai, lekin aap par usually koi criminal consequence nahi hota. Law victim ko case “withdraw” karne ka formal option nahi deta; investigation/court hi decide karte hain.

input: Ek aur doubt: jab pehle din police 161 CrPC statement leti hai, aur baad mein 164 CrPC before Magistrate hota hai, phir trial mein child apna version badal deti hai. Best practice kya hai ki POCSO Section 24 ke child-friendly principles follow hote hue bhi statement jaldi aur stable tarike se record ho, taaki later hostility ka risk kam ho?
output:
Practical best practices:

1) Jaldi se 164 CrPC statement arrange karein, kyunki Magistrate ke saamne diya hua statement zyada weight carry karta hai.
2) POCSO Section 24 ke mutabik child‑friendly environment: neutral jagah, familiar person, female officer where possible, no uniform ka intimidation.
3) CWC/ counsellor/ support person (POCSO Rules) ko involve karein, taaki [Victim] ko emotional support mile.
4) Family ko samjhayen ki statement sachayi par based ho aur later pressure ya compromise ke liye change karna child ke interest ke khilaaf hai.

input: Court stage par jab prosecutrix hostile ho jati hai, Public Prosecutor Evidence Act Section 154 ke under usse cross-examine kar sakta hai. NGO ke point of view se, hum PP ko practically kya suggest kar sakte hain? Kya woh uske 161/164 CrPC statements se confront karke POCSO Section 8 ka offence fir bhi prove kar sakte hain, ya hostile witness ke baad chances bohot kam ho jate hain?
output:
PP ke paas kuch options hote hain:

1) Evidence Act Section 154 se witness ko hostile declare karwa kar uske 161/164 CrPC statements se confront karein.
2) 164 CrPC statement ko corroborative evidence ke taur par use karke contradictions highlight karein.
3) Medical, site plan, prompt FIR, independent witnesses (agar ho) ko emphasize karein.

Lekin jab child completely incident deny kar de, especially POCSO Section 7/8 jaise cases mein, conviction statistically mushkil ho jata hai, kyunki main direct evidence weak ho chuka hota hai.

input: Protection angle se: agar hume lagta hai ki [Victim] par ghar ya community se pressure aa raha hai isliye woh hostile ho rahi hai, toh kaunse legal tools use kar sakte hain? Kya POCSO Section 33(7) ya witness protection scheme ya bail cancellation application use karke court se specific directions mangna possible hai, aur NGO ka role kya ho sakta hai?
output:
Haan, kuch options hain:

1) PP ke through application move karwa sakte hain ki court POCSO Section 33(7) ke under intimidation/harassment rokne ke directions de.
2) Agar accused bail par ho aur witness ko threaten kar raha ho, toh prosecution bail cancellation ya stricter conditions maang sakti hai.
3) State Witness Protection Scheme ka invocation, jisme relocation, non‑disclosure of identity, etc. ho sakta hai.
4) NGO written information court/PP/CWC ko de kar risk highlight kare, taaki official action trigger ho.

input: Training material bana rahe hain jahan hum is tarah ke acquittal cases discuss karenge. Aap suggest karenge ki field paralegals ko kaun‑se 4–5 core learning points batayein, specially POCSO Section 19 reporting, child counselling, statement recording, aur court support ke context mein, taaki Lakhan type matters mein at least process child‑centric aur legally sound ho?
output:
Key learning points:

1) Mandatory reporting: POCSO Section 19 explain karein, good‑faith protection bhi batayein, aur documentation proper rakhein.
2) Early, child‑friendly statement: police ko Section 24 POCSO principles remind karein, timely 164 CrPC arrange karne par follow‑up karein.
3) Counselling & safety: CWC referral, Childline 1098, counsellor/support person involve karna; family pressure identify karna.
4) Court support: in‑camera trial, separate waiting area, PP ke through unnecessary questions oppose karna.
5) Continuous follow‑up: har hearing pe presence/phone follow‑up, taaki child drop‑out/hostility ka risk kam ho.

input: Main ek NGO ke through ek 16-year-old [Minor] ka case dekh raha hoon, jiske khilaf POCSO ke under FIR hai aur wo ab Juvenile Justice Board ke saamne hai. Bail application JJ Act Section 12 ke under file hui hai. Court ko “presumption of innocence” aur “probability of association with known criminals” wale ground ko kaise balance karna chahiye? Aur hum NGO ki taraf se kaun se specific documents/evidence den ki planning karein jo safe environment aur rehabilitation potential ko show karein?
output: JJ Act Section 12 ke hisaab se bail deny tabhi ho sakti hai jab concrete risk ho ki [Minor] dobara offence karega, kisi known criminal ke contact mein aayega, ya uski safety khatre mein hogi. X Juvenile jaisa case yahi bolta hai ki sirf general suspicion kaafi nahi. Aap NGO ki taraf se yeh evidence de sakte hain: detailed home verification, school/tuition attendance records, counselling notes, guardian ka affidavit, aur supervised rehabilitation plan, jisme clear ho ki safe, structured environment available hai.

input: Agar prosecution argue kare ki locality mein kaafi anger hai, aur bail se community backlash ya [Victim] ke “re-victimisation” ka risk hai, kya yeh JJ Act Section 12 ke “ends of justice” ground ke under bail reject karne ka valid basis ban sakta hai? Kya hum written submissions mein JJ Act Section 3 (best interest principle) aur POCSO Section 40 (support person / victim support framework) ko cite karke controlled bail with conditions propose kar sakte hain?
output: Prosecution ka concern consider hoga, lekin JJ Act Section 12 ke context mein sirf community anger se bail deny nahi karni chahiye. Victim ki protection zaroor weigh hogi, par uske liye strict conditions lag sakti hain: no-contact order, alag school/area, periodic supervision, counselling. Aap submissions mein JJ Act Section 3 (best interest of child), child-friendly justice principles, aur POCSO Section 40 (support person, victim support framework) cite kar sakte hain, dikhate hue ki structured bail se dono children ke rights better protect ho sakte hain.

input: Ab hum social background report draft kar rahe hain. Kya isme explicitly mention karna strategic hoga ki family ke koi criminal antecedents nahi, stable housing/income hai, [Minor] ka school attendance theek hai, aur community mentorship available hai, taaki “association with known criminals” ka apprehension rebut ho? Doosra, jab juvenile POCSO ke under conflict with law hai, kya Child Welfare Committee ko parallel intimation dena JJ framework ke under mandatory hai, ya sirf JJB ke samne hi proceed karna sufficient hai?
output: Social background report mein clearly likhna useful hai ki family ka criminal record clean hai, income stable hai, [Minor] regular schooling/skills training karta hai, aur positive role models available hain. Isse “association with known criminals” wala ground weaken hota hai. Juvenile in conflict with law ke cases mein primary forum Juvenile Justice Board hai; CWC ko tab intimation dena practical hota hai jab family unsafe/neglectful ho, ya [Minor] ko care and protection ki bhi zarurat ho. Mandatory reporting POCSO Section 19 ke through FIR se cover ho chuki hoti hai.

input: Sir please help, main 61 saal ka hoon, school me kaam karta tha. Ek social worker ne bachcho ka workshop liya, uske baad kuch ladkiyon ne bola ki maine unko galat touch kiya. Main kasam se kuch galat nahi kiya. Ab police bula rahi hai, bol rahe case banega. Main bahut dar gaya hoon, kya hoga mere saath?
output: Aapka darr samajh sakta hoon. Jab minor ke baare me aisi complaint aati hai, to generally police FIR register karti hai, POCSO aur IPC ke Sections ke under. Iska matlab yeh nahi ki aap automatically guilty hain. Aapko right hai lawyer rakhne ka, silent rehne ka jo self‑incriminating ho. Court evidence dekhegi – bachchon ke statements, circumstances, kya sexual intent tha. Aise cases me bail mil sakti hai, especially jab allegations clear na hon.

input: Unhone bas itna bola ki maine shoulder pakda, bag utha diya, kabhi class me paas se nikla. Koi clear baat nahi boli. Lekin social worker ne bola yeh bhi galat touch hai. Kya itni baat pe bhi bada case ban sakta hai? Main seedha jail chala jaunga kya?
output: Law ke hisaab se, agar koi "physical contact" sexual intent se ho, to woh POCSO Section 7–8 (sexual assault) ke under aa sakta hai, aur IPC Section 354, 354A bhi lag sakte hain. Lekin sirf touch ka hona kaafi nahi, prosecution ko sexual intention dikhani hoti hai. Agar statements vague hon, sab ek jaise template jaisi hon, specific details na hon, to court isko dhyan se dekhti hai. Arrest possible hai, par aapke lawyer bail application file kar sakte hain.

input: Abhi police ne bola station aao, statement dena hai. Mujhe samajh nahi aa raha kya bolun. Agar main social worker ke bare me bolo ki woh galat samjha rahi hai bachchiyon ko, to mere khilaaf aur bura ho jayega kya?
output: Station jaane se pehle kisi criminal lawyer se milna better hai. Police aapse Section 161 CrPC ka statement legi; aapko jhooth nahi bolna, bas facts simple rakho. Aap keh sakte hain ki aapne sirf routine tarike se help ki, koi galat niyat nahi thi. Social worker ya bachchiyon ke against kuch bhi aggressive ya threatening mat bolo. Agar magistrate ke saamne Section 164 statement record hoga, wahaan bhi calmly sach batana hai.

input: Agar kal ko court mujhe bail de deta hai to kya case khatam ho jayega? Ya phir bhi trial hoga? School ne to abhi se mujhe nikal diya hai, reputation kharab ho gayi, main bahut tension me hoon.
output: Bail sirf yeh hota hai ki aap investigation/trial ke dauran jail ke bahar rahenge, case khatam nahi hota. Police charge‑sheet file karegi, phir trial chalega, witnesses – including bachchiyaan – court me depose karengi, child‑friendly procedure POCSO me diya gaya hai. Aapke lawyer unse cross‑examination kara sakte hain, contradictions dikhane ki koshish karenge. Job ka issue alag service/labour law ka matter hai, jisme aap separately challenge kar sakte hain, par wo guaranteed nahi.

input: Workshop me bachchiyon ko bola gaya tha ki agar koi bhi touch bura lage to turant bolo. Shayad unhone normal cheez ko bhi galat samajh liya ho. Kya court yeh cheez consider karega? Koi aisa matter hua hai jahan sirf aise vague allegations pe bail mil gayi ho?
output: Court context ko bhot seriously dekhta hai – workshop ka background, bachchiyon ke uniform ya copied jaisi statements, specific sexual act ka mention hai ya nahi, sab cheezein. Kai High Court judgments me, jab allegations sirf general touch ya unclear hote, sexual intent clearly nahi dikhti, to bail de di gayi, par trial chalta raha. Final decision evidence ke baad hi hota hai. Agar kabhi real abuse ho, to Childline 1098, police, ya JJ Act ke through Child Welfare Committee bhi help kar sakti hai.

input: Maine recently ek High Court judgment padha jahan 6 saal ke ladke ke saath sexual assault hua tha, trial court ne life imprisonment diya tha lekin High Court ne 15 saal kar diya. Mujhe samajhna hai, court sentence kam kyu karti hai aise POCSO cases me? Kya isse message galat nahi jata ki crime serious nahi hai?
output: Aapka concern bilkul valid hai. Court generally conviction ko uphold karti hai, lekin sentence decide karte waqt kuch factors dekhti hai: accused ki age, past criminal record, case ki specific circumstances, minimum–maximum punishment jo POCSO allow karta hai. Life se 15 years karna iska matlab yeh nahi ki crime kam serious hai, sirf itna ki court ko laga ki is case ke facts ke hisaab se 15 years + fine + other conditions kaafi hain. Child protection fir bhi central focus hi rehta hai.

input: Agar mere ek relative ke 7 saal ke bete ke saath neighbour [Accused] ne aisa kuch kiya ho, jaise anal sexual assault, to humko practical steps kya lene chahiye? Kaun kaun se law apply honge – POCSO, IPC? Aur sabse pehle FIR file karein ya pehle hospital le jayein?
output: Sabse pehle [Victim] ki safety aur health: 1) Turant safe jagah par le jayein, 2) Closest government hospital ya medico-legal centre me medical examination ke liye le jayein, yahan se hi police intimation bhi hoti hai. 3) FIR local police station me ya 112 dial karke. Is type ke case me generally POCSO Act ke under penetrative/aggravated penetrative sexual assault (Sections 3–6) apply hote hain, saath me IPC Section 376/377 bhi lag sakte hain. POCSO Section 19 ke hisaab se suchna dena mandatory hai.

input: Medical examination ka process child ke liye kaafi scary lagta hai. Kya law me koi protection hai ki doctor ya police usko gently treat karein? Statement kaise record hota hai POCSO me, bachche ko bar‑bar kahani nahi batani padti?
output: POCSO child‑friendly procedure pe zor deta hai. Hospital me ideally same gender doctor, parent/guardian ki presence allow hoti hai, unnecessary tests avoid karne chahiye. Statement ke liye: police ko POCSO Section 24 ke mutabik child‑friendly tarike se, possible ho to ghar ya comfortable jagah par statement lena chahiye. Baad me Magistrate ke saamne statement record ho sakta hai (CrPC/POCSO framework), jisse bachche ko baar‑baar repeat na karna pade. Aap lawyer se request kar sakte hain ki unnecessary cross‑questioning se bachche ko protect kiya jaye.

input: Agar family shame ki wajah se turant nahi bataye, aur maan lijiye ek mahine baad complaint kare, to kya court ya police bol sakti hai ki itni delay hai isliye case weak hai? Especially child sexual abuse me delay ka kya effect hota hai?
output: Child sexual abuse cases me delay common hai – dar, dhamki, shame, family pressure sab reason hote hain. Law aur courts generally maanta hain ki sirf delay ki wajah se case automatically weak nahi ho jata. Police ko FIR register karni hi chahiye, chahe delay ho. Court later dekhegi ki delay ka explanation reasonable hai ya nahi. Especially jab victim minor ho, courts zyada sensitive approach leti hain. Important hai ki jitni jaldi possible ho, ab complaint, medical records, counselling sab start kiya jaye.

input: Sentencing ke bare me ek doubt hai: agar [Accused] young ho, jaise 20–22 saal ka, to kya court aksar punishment kam karti hai jaise us judgment me life se 15 years kiya tha? Kya koi minimum punishment fixed hota hai POCSO me?
output: POCSO me kaafi offences ke liye statutory minimum punishment fixed hai. Penetrative sexual assault ke aggravated form ke liye (Section 6) minimum 10 years se life imprisonment tak ka range hai. Court isse kam nahi de sakti, par 10, 12, 15, 20 years, life – jo bhi decide karegi, wo facts, brutality, victim ki age, [Accused] ka conduct, remorse, past record sab dekh kar karegi. Sirf young age ki wajah se sentence automatic kam nahi hota; child ke interest ko primary importance milta hai.

input: Last cheez, family ko support kaha se milega? Counselors, legal aid, etc. Aur kya [Victim] ka naam media me aa sakta hai ya law me isko protect kiya gaya hai? Confidentiality ke bare me thoda bata dijiye.
output: Aap log free legal aid ke liye District Legal Services Authority (DLSA) approach kar sakte hain, Childline 1098 par call kar sakte hain, aur kai cities me One Stop Centres, counsellors available hote hain. Media ke liye POCSO Section 23 aur IPC rules ke hisab se child victim ki identity publish karna mana hai – naam, photo, address disclose nahi kiya ja sakta. Court proceedings me bhi usually in‑camera trial hota hai. Aap lawyer se specifically confidentiality aur protection orders ke liye request kar sakte hain.

input: Please help… I am very scared. My small girl was hurt by the religious teacher in her class. I am the mother. I was in shock and first told some people in our community, not police. Later police came and now they made me also accused, saying I did not report. Will they put me in jail? I dont understand what is happening.
output:
I am really sorry this happened to your child and to you. Your fear and confusion are completely normal.

In these cases, the law for protection of children (POCSO Act) says any person who knows about sexual abuse must report to police (Section 19). Not reporting can be punished (Section 21). But the court will also see your situation: shock, fear, whom you told first.

Please meet a criminal lawyer quickly. You can also ask for free legal aid if you cannot afford one.

input: I told the madrasa people and some elders the same day. Police complaint happened only later. I did not want to hide it, I was just scared and confused. Will court see that? My child is very scared to go to court and talk. Will they force her to speak in front of that man?
output:
Yes, your lawyer can show that you told community members first and that you did not intend to protect the teacher. Any messages, calls, or witnesses can help.

For your child, the POCSO Act says procedures must be child‑friendly (Sections 24 and 33). Evidence is often taken in a closed courtroom, without public, and questions should be gentle. Serious acts like this may fall under Sections 3–10 of POCSO and Section 354 or 354A IPC.

You can also ask for counselling and support through the Child Welfare Committee.

input: I feel guilty… Sometimes I think maybe stop this case so my child does not suffer more. Can I tell court I dont want to continue against the teacher? Then maybe they will also forgive me?
output:
Your feelings are understandable, but in such child sexual abuse cases the State prosecutes; it is not a private case you can withdraw. Courts treat these offences very seriously, similar to other sexual offences under POCSO and IPC (like Section 376 IPC for rape).

What you can do is: through your lawyer, ask the court for in‑camera proceedings, minimal questioning, and protective measures for your child. The judge can try to reduce her trauma while still ensuring the case is properly heard.

input: About my own case… they say I did wrong by not going to police first. But I never wanted to protect that man. Can this case on me be cancelled? I am so afraid of jail, I have other children also.
output:
The case against you seems related to the duty to report under POCSO (Section 21). A lawyer can ask the trial court to discharge you if evidence shows you acted in good faith and reported as soon as you could.

In some cases, people approach the High Court to quash the case under Section 482 of the Criminal Procedure Code. Outcomes depend on facts and evidence; no one can promise a result. Keep all proof that you did not hide the incident and cooperated with police.

input: I have no money for big lawyer. Police also talk very rough, I feel afraid to go there. Is there any place I can get help and someone to speak for me and my child?
output:
You have a right to support, even if you have no money.

1. Contact the District Legal Services Authority at your local court for free legal aid.
2. Call Childline 1098 for child protection support.
3. You can also call the women’s helpline 181 in many States.
4. Ask for a “support person” for your child under POCSO and help under the Juvenile Justice Act.

Police must treat you with respect. If they misbehave, you may complain to a senior officer or the Superintendent of Police.

input: Sir please help, mere cousin ki beti ke case me problem ho gaya hai. Police ne bol diya child case hai, par uski age ka proof clear nahi hai, school record me bhi confusion hai. Ab wo ladki bol rahi hai ki use case nahi chalana, dar lag raha hai, samajh nahi aa raha kya hoga, jail chala jayega kya aadmi? Hum kya karein?
output: Main samajh sakta hoon aap bohot tension me hain. Law ke hisaab se POCSO tabhi apply hota hai jab [Victim] ki age clearly 18 se kam prove ho. Court normally birth certificate, school record, ya medical age test dekhta hai. Agar age doubtful ho, kai baar benefit [Accused] ko mil sakta hai. Aur agar [Victim] court me keh de ki wo case nahi chalana chahti, to prosecution weak ho jata hai. Aap kisi criminal lawyer aur Childline 1098 se baat kar sakte hain.

input: Agar age clear prove na ho payi to kya case pura khatam ho sakta hai? Police bol rahi thi ki ye serious wala child offence hai, par ab ladki ne last baar court me bola ki mujhe case nahi chalana. Kya judge fir bhi saja de sakta hai? Hum log bhi confuse hain, koi galat faisla na ho jaye.
output: Court ko pehle ye dekhna hota hai ki kya [Victim] us time minor thi ya nahi. Agar age 18 se kam proper evidence se prove na ho, to POCSO wale charges gir sakte hain, phir sirf IPC ke normal offences dekhe jaate hain. [Victim] ka statement ki wo case nahi chalana chahti, isse prosecution ka case kamzor ho sakta hai, par final decision judge ka hota hai. Case simply “withdraw” nahi hota, State vs [Accused] rehta hai. Zaroor ek experienced criminal lawyer lein.

input: Police ne bola age ke liye medical test hoga, par family dar rahi hai, ladki already mentally disturbed hai. Kya ye medical zaroori hota hai? Kyunki birth proof clear nahi hai, sirf purane school ka kuch record hai, wo bhi exact nahi. Agar medical na karwayein to koi problem hogi?
output: Law me general practice ye hai: pehle birth certificate, phir school records, aur jab ye clear na hon tab hi medical age test (ossification, etc.) liya jata hai. Courts ne kai judgments me ye hierarchy use ki hai. Medical test helpful ho sakta hai, lekin wo child‑friendly tareeke se, preferably lady doctor se hona chahiye. Aap doctor aur lawyer se clearly discuss kar sakte hain. Agar family uncomfortable ho, to apni concerns court ya Investigating Officer ko likhit me batana useful hoga.

input: Agar baad me ladki bole ki usko exact age ya incident theek se yaad nahi, ya pehle pressure me kuch aur bol diya tha, to kya uske khilaf jhooth bolne ka case ban sakta hai? Humko dar hai ki kahin usi ko hi punish na kar dein. Use already bohot guilt feel ho raha hai.
output: Normally courts bachchon ke against jhooth bolne ka case (perjury) nahi chalate, kyunki POCSO ka purpose child ko protect karna hai, punish nahi. Judges samajhte hain ki minor par family, police ya society ka pressure ho sakta hai, isliye statements me contradictions aa jati hain. Sabse zaroori hai ki [Victim] ab jo bhi bole, without pressure, honestly bole. Wo apni confusion bhi judge/magistrate ko bata sakti hai. Aap legal aid (District Legal Services Authority) aur Childline 1098 se free support le sakte hain.

input: Main ek NGO mein paralegal hoon. Ek 12-year-old [Victim] ne school counsellor ko bataya ki ghar pe ek [Relative] uske saath sexual abuse kar raha hai, mostly touching aur intimidation type. Counsellor ne hume informal tarah se bataya, lekin abhi tak police ko nahi. Child filhaal parents ke saath hi reh raha hai aur parents bhi complaint lene mein hesitant hain. Is situation mein POCSO Section 19 ke hisaab se mandatory reporting counsellor pe bhi apply hota hai? NGO ki legal duty kya banti hai, aur anonymity ka kya scope hai?
output: Is situation mein POCSO Section 19 ke under “any person” jisko abuse ki knowledge hai, us par mandatory reporting ka obligation aata hai – isme school counsellor aur NGO dono aa sakte hain. FIR ke liye nearest police station ya Special Juvenile Police Unit (SJPU) approach kar sakte hain. Report likhwaate waqt aap request kar sakte hain ki child ka naam media ya public record mein disclose na ho (POCSO Section 23, IPC 228A). NGO ka role: complaint draft karna, police ke samne assist karna, aur Childline 1098 ko bhi inform karna.

input: Child ko humne temporary shelter home mein shift kar diya hai, safety thodi better hai, lekin disclosure ko 2–3 weeks ho chuke hain. Delay ko lekar hume concern hai ki defence baad mein use karega. Kya itni delay se case weak ho sakta hai? Ab hum Section 164 CrPC statement plan kar rahe hain. Kya hum specifically request kar sakte hain: female IO, child-friendly environment, possible video-conference recording, aur ek trained support person as per POCSO Rules?
output: Sexual abuse matters mein delay common hai aur trauma, fear, family pressure ko courts consider karte hain; sirf delay se case automatically weak nahi ho jata. Aap application mein clearly reasons mention karein. Police se likhit request kar sakte hain ki investigation female officer kare (POCSO Section 24), statement child-friendly jagah pe ho. Section 164 CrPC statement ke time Magistrate se in-camera, comfortable set-up aur breaks ki request karein. POCSO Rules ke hisaab se support person appoint ho sakta hai; NGO ka trained worker bhi propose kar sakte hain.

input: Ab hume yeh bhi dikh raha hai ki parents child ko blame kar rahe hain, uski baat ignore kar rahe hain, aur kabhi-kabhi threaten bhi karte hain ki “complaint wapas lo”. Is tarah ka mental cruelty/neglect legally kaise cover hota hai? Kya JJ Act Section 75 ya koi aur provision apply ho sakta hai? Saath hi, kuch relatives ne WhatsApp par child ka naam share kar diya hai, is identity disclosure ke against kaunse sections (POCSO/IPC/IT Act) use kiye ja sakte hain?
output: Agar parents jaan-boojhkar child ko intimidate kar rahe hain ya uski safety neglect ho rahi hai, toh Juvenile Justice Act Section 75 (cruelty to child) examine kiya ja sakta hai, aur Child Welfare Committee ko refer karna zaroori hoga. POCSO Section 21 mein failure to report/record ke liye punishment hai, especially agar koi responsible person ho. Identity disclosure ke liye POCSO Section 23 directly prohibit karta hai; IPC Section 228A rape/sexual offence victims ki identity protect karta hai. WhatsApp circulation ke context mein IT Act Section 67B ka bhi assessment ho sakta hai, facts ke hisaab se.

input: NGO level par hum ek written SOP banana chahte hain jo school ke saath share ho: stepwise process for mandatory reporting, documentation, interaction with police, aur electronic evidence (WhatsApp chats, screenshots, recordings) ko preserve karna. Target yeh hai ki child se baar‑baar detailed narration na karwani pade. Aap briefly suggest kar sakte hain ki SOP mein minimum kya-kya points aur timelines include hon, taaki POCSO compliance bhi ho aur re‑traumatisation bhi kam ho?
output:
SOP mein yeh key points rakhein:
1) Immediate safety assessment, agar risk ho toh same day Childline 1098 / police / CWC inform.
2) Single-point contact person (NGO/school) jo child se sirf basic, open-ended questions puche; detailed narration sirf police/Magistrate ke saamne.
3) Mandatory reporting timeline: disclosure ke 24 hours ke andar information police/SJPU ko (Section 19 POCSO reference).
4) Documentation: date–time, exact words as far as possible, bina leading questions.
5) Evidence preservation: original device secure, screenshots print + soft copy, chain-of-custody note.
6) Child-friendly coordination for Section 24/164 CrPC statements.

input: Ab [Accused] relative ne bail application file ki hai. Child bohot fearful hai ki agar woh bahar aaya toh family pressure aur intimidation badh jayega. NGO as support organisation prosecution ko kya inputs de sakta hai? Kya hum bail conditions ke liye specifically no-contact, residence se distance, aur witness tampering ke against strict conditions suggest kar sakte hain? Kya Section 164 CrPC statement ko use karke court ko dikhaya ja sakta hai ki child ko baar‑baar present karwana harmful hoga?
output:
Bail stage par NGO prosecution ko written note de sakta hai jisme:
- Child ki safety concerns aur existing threats detail ho.
- Strong bail conditions suggest kare: no-contact with [Victim], family members, witnesses; area restriction; regularly police station mein marking; social media se harassment na kare.
CrPC Sections 437(3), 439 ke tahat aisi conditions maangi ja sakti hain. POCSO Section 33(7) child se direct contact prohibit karne ka base de sakta hai. Section 164 CrPC statement ko court ke saamne rakha ja sakta hai taaki frequent appearance ki zaroorat kam ho, aur trial in-camera (POCSO Section 36) request ki ja sakti hai.

input: My younger brother [Accused] has been convicted by a Special Mahila Court under POCSO for aggravated sexual assault and given 7 years. The order mentions Section 9(m) read with Section 10. Can you explain in simple terms what this means? Also, they said appeal is under Section 374(2) CrPC to the High Court. What does the High Court usually look at in such appeals?
output:
I am sorry your family is going through this. Under POCSO:
- Section 7 defines “sexual assault” (physical contact with sexual intent, without penetration).
- Section 9 lists “aggravated sexual assault”. Clause (m) covers sexual assault on a child below 12 years.
- Section 10 gives punishment: minimum 5 years, up to 7 years + fine.
Section 374(2) CrPC allows an appeal by a convicted person to the High Court. The High Court mainly checks whether the trial was fair, evidence was properly appreciated, and whether the conviction and sentence are legally justified.

input: In our case, the allegation is that [Accused] touched the private part of [Victim] (a small child) over clothes. There is no medical evidence and no other witness, only the child’s statement. Can such touching be treated as aggravated sexual assault? And can someone be convicted only on the basis of the child’s testimony?
output:
Under POCSO:
- Section 7 says sexual assault includes touching private parts with sexual intent, even over clothes.
- If the child is under 12, it usually becomes “aggravated” under Section 9(m), punished under Section 10.
Courts can convict based only on the child’s testimony if it is consistent, trustworthy, and recorded properly (often under Section 164 CrPC), and if cross‑examination does not shake it. Lack of medical evidence does not automatically mean acquittal, especially where there is no penetration. The appeal can still question credibility and contradictions.

input: Suppose the High Court feels the incident happened but was less serious than what the trial court assumed. Can they reduce the sentence or change the section, like to a lesser POCSO offence or some IPC section? My brother has already been in jail for about three years. Does that make any legal difference?
output:
Yes, the High Court has powers to:
- Confirm conviction but reduce the sentence, or
- Alter the conviction to a lesser offence (for example from aggravated to simple sexual assault under Sections 7/8 POCSO, or sometimes to IPC Section 354).
It depends on facts: age, gravity, past record, and circumstances.
Time already spent in custody is set off against the sentence under Section 428 CrPC. During appeal, your lawyer can also seek suspension of sentence and bail under Section 389 CrPC, but that is discretionary.

input: The Special Court judgment is from December 2017, and we filed the appeal only in 2019 with help from legal aid. Will this delay cause problems? Also, what documents or records are usually important for the lawyer to argue such an appeal properly?
output:
Delay in filing a convict’s appeal can be condoned if you show reasons (poverty, lack of legal help, etc.). Courts are usually sympathetic when the person is in custody.
Important records include:
- Judgment and order on sentence of the Special Court
- FIR and charge‑sheet
- Statements under Sections 161 and 164 CrPC
- Deposition of [Victim], parents, doctors, police
- Medical and age‑determination reports
- Any defence evidence.
A lawyer will study these to identify inconsistencies, procedural lapses, or grounds for reducing the sentence.

input: Will [Victim] have to come again to the High Court and give evidence if we pursue the appeal fully? We do not want the child to be traumatised further, even though we are challenging the conviction.
output:
Your concern for the child is important. In an appeal, the High Court usually decides based on the trial record. Re‑examining the child is rare and only if absolutely necessary.
POCSO and CrPC encourage child‑friendly procedures:
- Section 33 and 36 POCSO: special care during evidence.
- Proviso to Section 273 CrPC: measures to prevent the child from seeing the accused directly.
If fresh evidence is needed, the Court can use video‑conferencing or other protective methods. The aim is to avoid re‑traumatising the child.

input: Separately, if someone in our neighbourhood suspects a child is being abused, what is their legal duty under POCSO? Is reporting mandatory, and how can they report safely without putting the child or themselves at risk?
output:
Under Section 19 POCSO, any person who suspects child sexual abuse must report it to the police or Special Juvenile Police Unit. Failure to report can be punished under Section 21.
Safe options:
- Call local police or women’s police station.
- Call CHILDLINE 1098.
- Inform the Child Welfare Committee or District Child Protection Unit.
- Approach the nearest Legal Services Authority for guidance.
The child’s statement should be recorded in a child‑friendly way under Section 24 POCSO. You can request confidentiality and avoid confronting the alleged abuser directly.

input: please help… my small girl was hurt in her playschool van by the driver… she was not even 3 years… I complained to police, they made a case on driver, teacher and ayah. but I am very scared… school people are acting like nothing happend. what does law say in this kind of thing? can they just go free?
output: I am very sorry this happened to your child. The law in India is very strict for this. What you describe usually comes under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, especially serious forms of sexual assault (for example Sections 3–6) and also Indian Penal Code offences like outraging modesty and rape (such as Sections 354, 376). These are serious, non‑bailable offences. They cannot “just go free”; but the court will decide based on evidence. Stay in touch with the Investigating Officer and public prosecutor.

input: I am so worried about my child… she is only 2 years 11 months, she barely talks… how will she go to court? I dont want her to suffer again or see those people. can anything be done to protect her? I dont understand how this works… please tell in simple way.
output: Your child’s safety and mental health come first. Under POCSO, her statement should be taken in a child‑friendly place, preferably by a woman officer (Section 24). The trial is in a Special Court, in a closed (in‑camera) room, and the judge can prevent the child from seeing the accused directly (for example by screens or video‑link). Repeated questioning is to be avoided. You can ask for a support person or counselor, and you can call Childline 1098 or the District Child Protection Unit for help.

input: Maine online ek POCSO bail ka case padha jahan court ne accused ko bail de di, kyunki prosecutrix ne kaha ki usne uske khilaf kuch nahi bola. Mujhe samajhna hai, agar ladki ya [Victim] later court me keh de ki usne allegation nahi lagaya tha, to kya POCSO ka case automatically khatam ho jata hai ya trial phir bhi chalta hai?
output:
Achha hai aap itna clearly samajhna chahte hain. Sirf [Victim] ka statement badalne se POCSO case automatically khatam nahi hota. Court poora record dekhta hai: FIR, Section 164 CrPC statement, medical, witnesses. 

POCSO ke offences (jaise Section 3–8) ko “serious” mana jata hai, isliye State (prosecution) case continue kar sakti hai. Lekin agar prosecutrix consistent tareeke se court me keh rahi hai ki accused ne kuch nahi kiya, to judge ko bail dene aur evidence ki reliability evaluate karne ka strong ground mil sakta hai.

input: Agar mere ek relative ke case me situation similar ho, [Minor] ne pehle police ko kuch bola tha, baad me keh rahi hai ki usne naam galat le liya, to kya is basis par accused ko bail mil sakti hai? Court kin cheezon ko dekhkar bail decide karegi POCSO matter me?
output:
Bail possible hai, lekin guarantee nahi. Court generally yeh cheezein dekhti hai:

1) [Minor] ke statements kitne consistent hain (police, magistrate, court).
2) Medical / forensic evidence hai ya nahi.
3) Case ki seriousness (penetrative ya non‑penetrative, POCSO Sections 3–10, IPC 354/376, etc.).
4) Accused ka criminal history, abscond karne ka risk.
5) Witness ko influence ya threaten karne ka risk.

Agar core allegation weak ya retract ho jaye, to CrPC Sections 437/439 ke under bail ke chances generally badh jate hain.

input: Agar bail mil bhi jaye to [Victim] ki safety ka kya hota hai? Kya court kuch conditions laga sakti hai? Jaise contact na kare, ghar ke paas na aaye, aise kuch? Victim ke rights aur protection ke options bata sakte hain, specially POCSO me?
output:
[Victim] ki safety sabse important hai. Court bail dete time conditions laga sakti hai, jaise:

- Accused [Victim]/family se contact nahi karega.
- Same area ya school/ghar ke aas‑paas nahi jayega.
- Witness ko influence ya threaten nahi karega.

POCSO me victim‑friendly process ka focus hai (Sections 19, 24). Victim ke rights:
- Safe recording of statement.
- In‑camera trial.
- Legal aid lawyer.

Aap protection ke liye local police, SP office, ya District Legal Services Authority se written application de sakte hain.

input: Agar kisi [Minor] ke saath aisa case ho aur family confused ho, to practical steps kya honge? Kahan approach karein—police, Childline, ya direct court? Aur kya bina paise ke legal help mil sakti hai POCSO matter me?
output:
Step‑by‑step aap yeh kar sakte hain:

1) Emergency me 1098 (Childline) ya 112 call karein.
2) Nearest police station me POCSO ke under FIR register karwayen; child‑friendly procedure demand karein.
3) District Hospital/authorised centre par medical examination (agar zaroori ho).
4) District Legal Services Authority (DLSA) me free legal aid ke liye application; POCSO victim ko normally free lawyer milta hai.
5) Agar threat ho to protection application court/police ko dein.

Jitni jaldi professional legal advice mile, utna behtar hoga.

input: Sir please help… meri age 17 thi jab [Accused1] ne shaadi ka promise karke mere saath bura kiya, fir mana kar diya. Maine FIR karwai. Dusra aadmi [Accused2] ne mujhe dhamki di thi. Ab suna hai court ne usko bail de di. Mujhe samajh nahi aa raha, kya iska matlab mera case khatam ho gaya? Main bahut dar rahi hoon.
output:
Mujhe afsos hai ki aapko yeh sab jhelna pad raha hai, aap ki feeling bilkul valid hai.

Bail milne ka matlab yeh nahi ki case khatam ya [Accused2] saaf ho gaya. Sirf itna ki jab tak trial chal raha hai, woh jail ke bahar rahega, kuch conditions ke saath. Aapka main case, jahan sexual assault hua, woh POCSO Section 3–4, 7–8 aur IPC Section 376, 354 ke under aa sakta hai. Dhamki dena IPC Section 506 ke under aata hai. Trial abhi bhi chalega.
